video.title: Harvard CS50 – Full Computer Science University Course
video.description:
Learn the basics of computer science from Harvard University. This is CS50, an introduction to the intellectual enterprises of computer science and the art of programming.

💻 Slides, source code, and more at https://cs50.harvard.edu/x. 

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (00:00:00) Lecture 0 - Scratch
⌨️ (01:45:08) Lecture 1 - C
⌨️ (04:13:23) Lecture 2 - Arrays
⌨️ (06:20:43) Lecture 3 - Algorithms
⌨️ (08:37:55) Lecture 4 - Memory
⌨️ (11:03:17) Lecture 5 - Data Structures
⌨️ (13:15:36) Lecture 6 - Python
⌨️ (15:39:25) Lecture 7 - SQL
⌨️ (18:00:55) Lecture 8 - HTML, CSS, JavaScript
⌨️ (20:23:38) Lecture 9 - Flask
⌨️ (22:39:01) Lecture 10 - Emoji
⌨️ (24:02:50) Cybersecurity

Recorded in 2021.

---

HOW TO JOIN CS50 COMMUNITIES

Discord: https://discord.gg/cs50
Ed: https://cs50.harvard.edu/x/ed
Facebook Group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/cs50/
Faceboook Page: https://www.facebook.com/cs50/
GitHub: https://github.com/cs50
Gitter: https://gitter.im/cs50/x
Instagram: https://instagram.com/cs50
LinkedIn Group: https://www.linkedin.com/groups/7437240/
LinkedIn Page: https://www.linkedin.com/school/cs50/
Medium: https://cs50.medium.com/
Quora: https://www.quora.com/topic/CS50
Reddit: https://www.reddit.com/r/cs50/
Slack: https://cs50.edx.org/slack
Snapchat: https://www.snapchat.com/add/cs50
SoundCloud: https://soundcloud.com/cs50
Stack Exchange: https://cs50.stackexchange.com/
TikTok: https://www.tiktok.com/@cs50
Twitter: https://twitter.com/cs50
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/cs50

HOW TO FOLLOW DAVID J. MALAN

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/dmalan
GitHub: https://github.com/dmalan
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/davidjmalan/
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/malan/
TikTok: https://www.tiktok.com/@davidjmalan
Twitter: https://twitter.com/davidjmalan

topLevelComment.author: Henry Lee
topLevelComment.text:
I would like to obtain a Bachelor's or Master's degree in Computer Science; However, I have been told by many Universities that I cannot attend a University as an undergrad twice. I have a bachelors of arts in another field, but I am feeling stuck right now.

Does anyone have any knowledge on what I can do?

replies.author: Maalik Serebryakov
replies.text:
(1) Negotiate with the Universities. Be persistent with them. 
Undergrad Admissions are much more negotiable than you think. Trust me. I cant be bothered explaining why I know that.

(2)if (1) doesnmt work  Find a university that doesn’t care if you’ve already done a bachelors. 


Dude

topLevelComment.author: Send Rain
topLevelComment.text: I don’t think I’m going to learn like this. Is he going to talk all animated and over enthusiastic for 24 hours? I need a tutor who will start with the very basics of teaching computer language first. What symbols mean and how they are used. How they create commands. Then move on to programming something very simple, basic but effective. Every time I try to play around with programming, I’m usually just copying someone else but never learning the language to remember “WHY” certain symbols must be used in order to program or code. Like learning the A B C’s.

topLevelComment.author: Nuric91
topLevelComment.text:
I really do not understand what this course has to do with computer science. It is misleading...
I really do not know any of my graduated university colleagues who are actually coding something.
Also, at university, I only had one programming course in the first semester. The rest was pure math and logic.

Every electrical engineer and machine builder has more coding experience after studying than a German computer scientist.
In Germany, it is also not called "Computer Wissenschaftler" (which is German for computer scientist). In Germany, it is called "Informatik," which is an acronym for "Informations Automatisierung," which means "information automation." So the German view of an "Informatiker" is of a person who develops mathematical descriptions for automatic information processing, such as AI, communication protocols, traffic flow on streets, search engines, and much more. It usually has nothing to do with actually coding.

So if you concentrate on coding, you are more like an engineer than a computer scientist. And it's not coding that makes the graduated computer scientist so wealthy; it's their mathematical talent

replies.author: William Moore
replies.text: @Nuric91 I'm currently in a degree program for computer science in the US and I can tell you are taking out of your ass. This is an intro level course. We cover more advanced knowledge in parallel or later in the program such as the engineering side. Engineering degrees in the US often do include some programming, but they do not go anywhere near as deep in detail as Computer Science degrees. I know because I was going for computer engineering but I wasn't happy that I was missing out on so much software knowledge; so I switched to Computer Science. I still have a lot of the stem requirements, it's a lot of math and logic, but programming is also included.

topLevelComment.author: Logan Moss CPT
topLevelComment.text:
Here is how I am approaching this course: 

Before I found this video, I watched about 5 hours worth of videos on the basics of python + a few hours of practice. That gave me a great baseline understanding of how code essentially works. 

Now, I am watching this video before bed just about every night. No notes. Just absorbing the passion Dr. Malan shows in this lecture. 

I do my notes and am in more of a "student" mode in other parts of the day. For example, I am working on the Google Certificate for Data Analytics. 

Find what works best for you! I just felt like taking notes on a 24 hour video just wasn't going to work for me :)

@UrsidaeCo He asked about degree vs skills. Even a fresh grad will have one internship experience or multiple from the larger comp sci schools. 

I have friends who now work at Fortune 500 companies who were bootcamp. But they had to work for non-profits, take smaller salaries, even paid internships after their bootcamp. The boomer generation CEOs/VPs/etc will literally put a wall behind "degree required" and we can't do much about it.

replies.text:
@Nuric91 tbh i disagree with you. I went to a community college so i didnt really learn the logic part in programming. We just wrote meaningless code to get a good grade. I felt like this guy explained the logic parts really well.

Also, idk about you but after i got all my math classes out the way, i never used any math other than basic algebra. But it does depend on what you go into after u graduate.

replies.author: Nuric91
replies.text:
@cellardior I think if you are good in math, you can then choose what language you want to use to describe it to your Maschine. It is very hard to describe komplex system. And by describe modelling it. 
So enhancing the "pure" math skill is the way to go. 

By pure, I do not mean the applicable math. I mean the Math which is all about abstract objects, rooms. How to prove statements in math. There is a reason, why computer science has been developed out of math.

If you are interested in design, layout and UI, experience is what counts. Then this is a good point to start, because you will never face such complex stuff. For computer science, it does not help at all.

For me for example, it does not matter which programming language is use. I can use most of them, because I'm capable of Mathe. BUT I am bad for example in the programming language R. Because I m bad I'm stochastic... Therefore, I am lacking the math skill to use it. 

If you are good in math, you can use every language to express your creativity.

replies.author: Bird
replies.text: Click on the link in the description of the video. Labeled as "Slides, source code, and more at".  Once you're in there, you can click on the corresponding week that lines up with the  timestamps (also in description).  The homework assignments are the "Problem Sets" within each week's material.  Week 1's Problem Set 1 gives instructions on how to log into the codespace (IDE is a Cloud Based machine running Ubuntu) for this CS50 course.  This will allow you to follow along with the professor, especially since it contains things like #include <cs50.h>, which is needed for much of the coding that takes place in the course.

topLevelComment.author: Jack
topLevelComment.text:
On the off chance anyone reads comments, I could use a hand:
At 3:55:47 he demonstrates his code to print a square grid of the # character based on the number input by the user. So like a 3x3 grid if the user inputs 3.

Why does this code print # in a square grid? How does it know that one of the for loops is horizontal and one is vertical?

My best guess is the placement of his printf("\n") as it is outside of the second for loop. So like, it runs the first for loop and prints #, then runs the second for loop over and over until it fills out that row. THEN it prints the \n new line and starts the first for loop over. I think that might be right?

If any geniuses have a succinct explanation though I would still appreciate it.

EDIT: I think I finally get it, and it's kinda cool to see precisely how wrong I was. I needed to check another video on nested loops.

Basically, the outer loop runs which causes the inner loop to run X amount of times. (X being the amount the user input). When the inner loop finishes those X number of loops, it moves on to the end of the outer loop which prints a new line and starts another run of the outer loop, which then leads to X amount of inner loops being completed again.

Feels incredibly satisfying to struggle intensely with this fairly basic concept but then come to understand it a couple hours later.

replies.author: james mining
replies.text: Hey. Seems you have figured out nested for loops! Each inner loop must run once for every run of the outer loop!

topLevelComment.author: obuw1
topLevelComment.text: As someone who graduated over 20 years ago with a CS degree, and as someone who has taught introductory CS courses at a local university for several years, I skimmed over random bits of this course, and I like how clearly he explains and demonstrates every topic from programming concepts like recursion to web concepts like cURL and CSS. I recall that the web section in particular was also part of our coursebook, but was never actually covered in class, I read through the chapters and learned them myself and the concepts are a crucial part of work I do nowadays.

I don't actually know enough about the game to point out any design flaws or make any comparisons.

topLevelComment.author: We the North
topLevelComment.text: I am a self taught programmer (IBM's CL language used in Midrange AS/400 computers) who learned to write programs by reading the code other programmers wrote and then writing my own through trial and error. I am no expert by any stretch but it was an added bonus when I taught myself computer operations by reading the manuals and being able to provide a better interpretation of the data. I was able to self educate enough to be able to manage Computer Departments for Billion dollar corporations and all because I was curious, able to read and understand the well written manuals and coded programs written by others. Oh how I wish I could have afforded a formal education let alone Harvard but this course offering is wonderful. Wouldn't it be amazing if all education was online and available to anyone with an internet connection, what a different world we would live in. Thanks Harvard.

topLevelComment.author: zdspider
topLevelComment.text:
Seems to be very superficial stuff. It won't cover _everything._ It can't. You try condensing 3-4 years (hundreds of hours) into ~25h! I saw about 50 minutes of it and he just skipped over how negative numbers are represented with bits. Explaining how floating point numbers work would take an entire lecture.
So don't think of this as "the ultimate course", or "everything you need". It's not. It seems like a good course, but it's just 1 course. You should be getting your information from _multiple_ sources. At some point it will start to click. Good luck with your studies!

topLevelComment.author: gargoyle
topLevelComment.text:
Ah yes the course that got me properly started on my journey into programming. I remember after a while I took part in a code golf thread on 4chan's technology board, the topic was text to ASCII code converters and I won by a landslide. Code golf is a game, not development, it's important to remember that. Yet these people were writing neat and very readable code, and that's how you lose :)


Their submissions were all between 15-50 lines. I simply posted:

for(int x;x=getchar();printf("%d ", x)); 

They complained so hard, that it's ugly, that it abuses the language (because they don't understand how it works... I'll explain later), that it didn't compile correctly on their obscure compiler, that I "incorrectly used the for() loop", that it doesn't count as a full program because it doesn't include all of the code needed to run it, so I fixed it:

#include <stdio.h>
int main(){for(int x;x=getchar();printf("%d ", x)); }

And they were somehow even more angry, but even though they tried to deny it, I won the game. It was a very memorable, beautiful moment.

For all the newbies learning from this video, it's an extremely simple program:
The for() loop keeps my program running until you exit.
I define a variable I called x and assign it to the "get character" function in the standard library.
By outputting the input as a number, you receive the corresponding ASCII code of that character or string.

And that's it, you can type a single character or a full paragraph then hit enter and boom, it display the code(s) and stays running, awaiting more input until you exit. 
It works flawlessly without a single error in the compiler. Anyways, that's how I won at code golf and made a lot of people very upset.

topLevelComment.text: Этот учебный курс Гарвардского Университета по CS (Компьютерным Наукам) хороший, но я еще раз убедился, что для изучения лекции важно, не только содержание курса, но и то, как читает его лектор и кто читает. Быстрый разговор и ношение защитной маски от вирусов, когда уже нет "пандемии" указывает на невротичность лектора. А лектор невротик психологически отрицательно влияет на студентов, не говоря о том, что эффект обучения у него низок. Мой совет, смотря этот курс, включите субтитры и останавливая это видео, чтобы прочесть фрагменты субтитров, читайте их.

topLevelComment.author: Towards The Sunset
topLevelComment.text:
This is not a great way to learn anything, in my opinion.

The best starting point is picking a language (doesn't matter, just pick one), and going through the documentation. All languages have excellent docs, especially these days, with "Getting Started" sections and guided tutorials.

Having a "professor" relay that information to you is not remotely as conducive to learning the concepts properly as reading it yourself, at your own pace, and being hands on with code at the same time.

Sorry to burst any bubbles, but people have been learning to code since World War 2, and they didn't have colleges or universities available to teach them.

replies.text: @Jsusbdndk @Jsusbdndk I'm not sure if my time frame would line up with yours. I was doing about 1 lecture and subsequent homework for a week - 2 weeks when I had time. The homework takes a while but is very rewarding. I was not able to watch a full lecture every day just fit it I to my limited time frame! The homework takes longer the deeper into the course you get. I was working full time about 60 hours per week and putting in a little time onto this! I started about late Feb 2022. I do believe the way the material is oriented that if you gave yourself a structured schedule and stuck with it you could absolutely achieve your goal!

replies.author: vonHübl
